header.title: Book of Enoch by R. Ishmael Ben Elisha the High Priest

central_thesis: The Book of Enoch by R. Ishmael Ben Elisha details a profound cosmological and angelological system revealed through R. Ishmael's visionary ascent to the heavenly Merkaba. Its central thesis revolves around the figure of Metatron, identified as the transfigured Enoch, who serves as the primary celestial mediator and revealer of divine secrets, embodying immense divine authority. The text describes the intricate structure of the heavens, the hierarchy and functions of myriad angelic hosts, the mechanics of creation through cosmic letters, and the processes of divine judgment and world sustenance, all governed and maintained through precise celestial operations and the power of divine names.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter I: Introduction: R. Ishmael ascends to heaven to behold the vision of the Merkaba and is given in charge to Metatron
structure_content.summary: R. Ishmael describes his visionary ascent through six heavenly Halls to the seventh, where he prays before the Holy One. Metatron, the Prince of the Presence, is dispatched to protect and guide R. Ishmael, revealing the Merkaba vision.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter II: The highest classes of angels make inquiries about R. Ishmael, which are answered by Metatron
structure_content.summary: High-ranking angels, including the 'eagles of the Merkaba', 'Ophannim, and Seraphim, question R. Ishmael's presence in heaven. Metatron intervenes, affirming R. Ishmael's lineage from Israel and Levi, which pacifies the questioning angels.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter III: Metatron has 70 names, but God calls him 'Youth'
structure_content.summary: R. Ishmael inquires about Metatron's name. Metatron reveals he possesses seventy names, corresponding to the seventy tongues (nations) of the world, but is uniquely called 'Youth' (Na'ar) by God.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter IV: Metatron is identical with Enoch who was translated to heaven at the time of the Deluge
structure_content.summary: Metatron discloses his identity as Enoch, son of Jared, who was translated to heaven as a witness against the sinful generation of the Flood. Angels ('Uzza, 'Azza, 'Azzael) protest his elevation, but God defends Enoch's role as a prince.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter V: The idolatry of the generation of Enosh causes God to remove the Shekina from earth. The idolatry inspired by 'Azza, 'Uzza and 'Azziel
structure_content.summary: The idolatry of Enosh's generation, influenced by 'Azza, 'Uzza, and 'Azziel, led to the withdrawal of the Shekina (Divine Presence) from Earth. This chapter sets the context for Enoch's translation as a divine response to terrestrial corruption.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VI: Enoch lifted up to heaven together with the Shekina. Angels' protests answered by God
structure_content.summary: Enoch (Metatron) is lifted to heaven by Anaphiel H on a fiery chariot, accompanied by the Shekina. Angels protest his human ascent, but God affirms Enoch's election due to his merits, making him a 'tribute' from the world.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VII: Enoch raised upon the wings of the Shekina to the place of the Throne, the Merkaba and the angelic hosts
structure_content.summary: Metatron recounts his ascent, borne on the wings of the Shekina, to the highest heaven, 'Araboth Raqia', where he witnessed the glorious Throne of Shekina, the Merkaba, and various fiery angelic hosts, and was appointed to serve the Throne daily.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter VIII: The gates (of the treasuries of heaven) opened to Metatron
structure_content.summary: God opened to Metatron 'three hundred thousand gates of Understanding', 'Subtlety', and 'Life', along with other divine attributes, thereby bestowing upon him unparalleled wisdom and honor, surpassing all other celestial beings.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter IX: Enoch receives blessings from the Most High and is adorned with angelic attributes
structure_content.summary: Metatron received 5360 blessings from God, was physically expanded to the size of the world, grew 72 wings (36 on each side), and was adorned with 365 eyes, each shining as a great luminary, receiving all celestial splendor.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter X: God places Metatron on a throne at the door of the seventh Hall and announces through the Herald, that Metatron henceforth is God's representative and ruler over all the princes of kingdoms and all the children of heaven, save the eight high princes called YHWH by the name of their King
structure_content.summary: God establishes Metatron on a Throne resembling the Throne of Glory, covered with a splendid curtain. A herald proclaims Metatron as God's representative ruler over all celestial princes and children of heaven, with the exception of eight supreme princes bearing the name YHWH.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XI: God reveals all mysteries and secrets to Metatron
structure_content.summary: Metatron is divinely granted comprehensive knowledge, including all mysteries of the Torah, secrets of wisdom, depths of the Perfect Law, thoughts of living beings, and secrets of Creation, enabling him to comprehend all past, present, and future events.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XII: God clothes Metatron in a garment of glory, puts a royal crown on his head and calls him "the Lesser YHWH"
structure_content.summary: God bestows upon Metatron a garment of glory adorned with divine lights, a robe of honor filled with splendor, and a royal crown embedded with forty-nine precious stones. He is uniquely named 'the Lesser YHWH', signifying his exalted status.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XIII: God writes with a flaming style on Metatron's crown the cosmic letters by which heaven and earth were created
structure_content.summary: God inscribes cosmic letters onto Metatron's crown, using a flaming style. These letters are the fundamental building blocks and divine blueprints by which all of creation (heaven, earth, seas, rivers, mountains, stars, etc.) was brought into being.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XIV: All the highest princes, the elementary angels and the planetary and sideric angels fear and tremble at the sight of Metatron crowned
structure_content.summary: Upon Metatron's crowning, all celestial princes, including Sammael (Prince of the Accusers) and angels governing fire, hail, wind, lightnings, thunder, snow, rain, day, night, sun, moon, planets, and constellations, are struck with fear and prostrate themselves before him.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XV: Metatron transformed into fire
structure_content.summary: Metatron's physical form undergoes a complete metamorphosis into fire: his flesh becomes flames, sinews fiery, bones burning coals, eyelids radiant lightnings, eyeballs fire-brands, and his entire body glowing fire, surrounded by fiery phenomena.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XVB: Addition occurring in B and L
structure_content.summary: Metatron stands before the Most High with a tabernacle of light. This section includes a narrative of Moses' ascent, fasting for 121 days, seeing the 'heart of the Lion', and being protected by Metatron from angels seeking to burn him. Human prayers are transformed into divine crowns.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XVI: Metatron divested of his privilege of presiding on a Throne of his own on account of Acker's misapprehension in taking him for a second Divine Power
structure_content.summary: Metatron, initially presiding on a great Throne and judging celestial beings, was temporarily divested of this privilege. This occurred after Acher (Elisha ben Abuya) mistakenly perceived Metatron as a second divine power, leading to Acher's apostasy. Anaphiel administered sixty fiery strokes to Metatron as a consequence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XVII: The princes of the seven heavens, of the sun, moon, planets and constellations and their suites of angels
structure_content.summary: Details the seven great archangels (e.g., Mikael, Gabriel, Shataqiel) presiding over the seven heavens, each accompanied by 496,000 myriads of ministering angels. Further, it lists the princes governing the sun, moon, planets, and constellations, each with their respective angelic retinues.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XVIII: The order of ranks of the angels and the homage received by the higher ranks from the lower ones
structure_content.summary: Describes a rigid angelic hierarchy where lower-ranked angels and princes (e.g., of the first heaven) remove their crowns and prostrate before higher-ranked ones (e.g., of the second heaven, up to the Door Keepers of the Seventh Hall and four Great Princes like Tag'as and Barattiel), demonstrating a cosmic order of reverence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XIX: Rikbiel, the prince of the wheels of the Merkaba. The surroundings of the Merkaba. The commotion among the angelic hosts at the time of the Qedushsha
structure_content.summary: Introduces Rikbiel H', prince of the Merkaba's wheels. Describes the Merkaba's eight wheels and the surrounding elemental forces (four winds, fiery rivers, clouds of fire). A universal commotion among all angelic hosts erupts during the Qedushsha chant.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XX: CHAYYLIEL, the prince of the Chayyoth
structure_content.summary: Introduces CHAYYLIEL H', a powerful and revered prince appointed over the Holy Chayyoth. He ensures the proper performance of the Qedushsha by smiting those who fail with fiery lashes and glorifying those who succeed.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXI: The Chayyoth
structure_content.summary: Describes the four Chayyoth (living creatures) that align with the four winds. Each is vast, covering the space of the world, possessing four faces and four universe-spanning wings. They are crowned with 2000 crowns, radiating splendor like the morning star.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXII: KERUBIEL, the Prince of the Kerubim. Description of the Kerubim
structure_content.summary: Details KERUBIEL H', the prince of the Kerubim. His fiery stature, mouth like a lamp of fire, consuming tongue, lightning-like eyebrows, and myriad eyes like sparks are described. He bears a crown of holiness engraved with the Explicit Name and a sword, while the Kerubim stand with Shekina resting upon them.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXII B: Merkabah (Additional)
structure_content.summary: This section describes a celestial court before the Throne of Glory, accessible via numerous bridges over fiery rivers that Seraphim cannot cross. It details three ministering angels uttering songs, surrounded by lords of dread and fear, and quantifies various celestial elements like rivers of hail, treasuries of snow, and wheels of fire, arranged in precise cosmic layers.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXII C: Merkabah (Additional) (in B, Lo and Lmr)
structure_content.summary: This chapter measures the vast distances between various celestial components in myriads of parasangs: bridges, rivers of dread/fear/hail/darkness, chambers of lightnings, clouds of compassion, the Merkaba, Kerubim, Ophannim, chambers of chambers, and the Holy Chayyoth, culminating at the Throne of Glory.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXIII: The winds blowing 'under the wings of the Kerubim'
structure_content.summary: Enumerates various winds blowing under the Kerubim's wings, each associated with specific cosmic or divine attributes: East Wind, Wind of Quails, Wind of Jealousy, Wind of Earthquake, Wind of H', Evil Wind (with Satan as the Storm-Wind), Wind of Wisdom/Understanding/Knowledge/Fear of H', Wind of Rain, Wind of Lightnings, Wind, Breaking the Rocks, and Wind of Assuagement of the Sea.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXIV: The different chariots of the Holy One, blessed be He
structure_content.summary: Lists and describes the numerous 'Chariots' of the Holy One, including the Chariots of Kerubim, Wind, Swift Cloud, Clouds, Altar, Ribbotaim (thousands of angels), Tent, Tabernacle, Mercy-Seat, Sapphire Stone, Eagles, Shout, 'Araboth, Thick Clouds, and Chayyoth, emphasizing their divine origins and the symbolism derived from scriptural passages.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXV: 'Ophphanniel, the prince of the 'Ophannim. Description of the 'Ophannim
structure_content.summary: Introduces 'OPHPHANNIEL H', the great prince overseeing the 'Ophannim. Describes the 'Ophannim as beings full of eyes and brightness, adorned with 72 sapphire stones on their garments and four carbuncle stones on their crowns, radiating splendor throughout the universe.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXVI: SERAPHIEL, the Prince of the Seraphim. Description of the Seraphim
structure_content.summary: Presents SERAPHIEL H', the supreme prince of the Seraphim. Describes his being filled with splendor and goodliness. The Seraphim are tasked with burning Satan's writing tables, which contain records of Israel's iniquities, to prevent their presentation to God and thus avert Israel's destruction. They possess knowledge of God's secrets and perform the Qedushsha.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXVII: RADWERIEL, the keeper of the Book of Records
structure_content.summary: Introduces RADWERIEL H', the celestial registrar who keeps the 'Book of Records'. He retrieves the Case of Writings, breaks its seals, and presents the records of all deeds before the Holy One and the Great Beth Din in 'Araboth Raqia' for judgment. Angels are said to be created from every word that issues from his mouth.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXVIII: The 'Irin and Qaddishin
structure_content.summary: Describes the 'Irin and Qaddishin as four (or numerous) great princes, superior to all other angels, dwelling near the Throne of Glory. They function as celestial court officers in the Great Beth Din, participating daily in God's judgment by arguing cases, passing sentences, and executing divine decrees, exalting the humble and abasing the proud.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXIX: The explicit names fly off from the Throne and all the various angelic hosts prostrate themselves before it at the time of the Qedushsha
structure_content.summary: During the angelic utterance of the 'Holy' chant, the explicit Divine Names engraved on the Fearful Crown of Glory detach and ascend like eagles. These names, infused with sparks and lightnings, are too brilliant for even the Seraphim and Chayyoth to behold, causing all angelic hosts to prostrate.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXX: The 72 princes of Kingdoms and the Prince of the World officiating at the Great Sanhedrin in heaven
structure_content.summary: Details the Great Beth Din in 'Araboth Raqia', where 72 princes of kingdoms, led by the Prince of the World (Metatron), serve as advocates for the nations before the Holy One. These princes bear divine names and represent the terrestrial nations in celestial judgment and cosmic governance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXXI: (The attributes of) Justice, Mercy and Truth by the Throne of Judgement
structure_content.summary: During God's daily judgment, the personified attributes of Justice, Mercy, and Truth are present. Justice stands on God's right, Mercy on His left (issuing a protective staff of splendor for man), and Truth before His face, mediating between the other two and revealing true judgment.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXXII: The execution of judgement on the wicked. God's sword
structure_content.summary: When God opens the 'Book', a fiery sword emerges from His presence to execute judgment on the wicked. This sharpened, lightning-like sword instills fear throughout the world, symbolizing divine retribution.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXXIII: The angels of Mercy, of Peace and of Destruction by the Throne of Judgement. The scribes, (vss. 1, 2) The angels by the Throne of Glory and the fiery rivers under it. (vss. 3-5)
structure_content.summary: At God's Throne of Judgment, angels of Mercy, Peace, and Destruction are stationed, and two scribes record human deeds. The chapter also describes the Seraphim, Ophannim, and Chayyoth surrounding the Throne of Glory, each possessing 'three fingers' and encompassed by clouds of fire and seven fiery rivers.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXXIV: The different concentric circles round the Chayyoth, consisting of fire, water, hailstones etc. and of the angels uttering the Qedushsha responsorium
structure_content.summary: Describes concentric circles surrounding the Chayyoth's hoofs: burning coals, fire, hailstones, 'wings of the tempest', and whirlwind, all interwoven with fire and water. Angels within these circles utter the 'Holy' and 'Blessed' chants, maintaining cosmic balance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXXV: The camps of angels in 'Araboth Raqia': angels, performing the Qedushsha
structure_content.summary: Describes 506,000 myriad angelic camps in 'Araboth Raqia', each containing 496,000 angels, all performing the Qedushsha. Prior to the chant, a divine whirlwind transforms the angels into fiery forms, until they accept the 'yoke of heaven' and revert to their original shape for the sacred utterance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXXVI: The angels bathe in the fiery river before reciting the 'Song'
structure_content.summary: Before reciting the 'Song' (Qedushsha), ministering angels undergo a ritual purification: they descend into the Nehar di-Nur (fiery stream), immerse themselves and their tongues seven times, then emerge clothed in 'Machaqe Samal' and chashmal cloaks to stand in four rows before the Throne of Glory.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXXVII: The four camps of Shekina and their surroundings
structure_content.summary: Details four chariots and four camps of Shekina within the seven Halls, each surrounded by a continuous river of fire, bright clouds, pillars of brimstone, flaming wheels, treasuries of lightnings, and the powerful forces of storm-wind and tempest.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXXVIII: The fear that befalls all the heavens at the sound of the 'Holy,' esp. the heavenly bodies. These appeased by the Prince of the World
structure_content.summary: The utterance of the 'Holy' chant by ministering angels causes all heavenly structures—pillars, gates, foundations, orders, constellations, planets, sun, and moon—to tremble and flee in terror, a commotion appeased only by the Prince of the World.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XXXIX: The explicit names fly off from the Throne and all the various angelic hosts prostrate themselves before it at the time of the Qedushsha
structure_content.summary: During the Qedushsha, the explicit Divine Names, engraved with flaming style on the Fearful Crown of Glory, detach and fly off like eagles, radiating intense brilliance that compels all angelic hosts to prostrate in reverence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XL: The ministering angels rewarded with crowns, when uttering the 'Holy' in its right order, and punished by consuming fire if not. New ones created in the stead of the consumed angels
structure_content.summary: Angels who correctly utter the 'Holy' are rewarded with crowns of stars. Conversely, those who fail to perform the chant in the right order are consumed by a divine fire emanating from God's finger, and new angels are instantly created to replace them and maintain the celestial liturgy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XLI: Metatron shows R. Ishmael the letters engraved on the Throne of Glory by which letters everything in heaven and earth has been created
structure_content.summary: Metatron reveals to R. Ishmael the cosmic letters engraved on the Throne of Glory. These letters are the foundational creative principles by which all components of the universe, including heaven, earth, mountains, seas, rivers, plants, and celestial bodies, were brought into existence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XLII: Instances of polar opposites kept in balance by several Divine Names and other similar wonders
structure_content.summary: Metatron demonstrates how polar opposites (e.g., waters suspended in fire, fire burning in hail, lightnings in snowy mountains, thunders roaring) are miraculously held in balance by specific Divine Names (e.g., YAH 'EHYE 'ASHER 'EHYE, 'ESH 'OKELA, YAH SUR 'OLAMIM, 'EL SHADDAI RABBA, YAD 'AL KES YAH, 'OSE SHALOM), emphasizing God's role as the 'Maker of Peace'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XLIII: Metatron shows R. Ishmael the abode of the unborn spirits and of the spirits of the righteous dead
structure_content.summary: Metatron reveals to R. Ishmael the dwelling place of the spirits of the righteous—both those already created and returned, and those yet to be created—residing in chambers of creation and flying above the Throne of Glory, highlighting the concept of pre-existent souls.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XLIV: Metatron shows R. Ishmael the abode of the wicked and the intermediate in Sheol. (vss. 1-6) The Patriarchs pray for the deliverance of Israel (vss. 7-10)
structure_content.summary: Metatron displays the spirits of the wicked and intermediate in Sheol, where angels of destruction (Za'aphiel for the wicked, Simkiel for the intermediate) administer fiery punishment or purification. The spirits' countenances reflect their deeds. The Patriarchs (Abraham, Isaac, Jacob) then supplicate God for Israel's deliverance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XLV: Metatron shows R. Ishmael past and future events recorded on the Curtain of the Throne
structure_content.summary: Metatron reveals the 'Curtain of MAQOM' (Divine Majesty), upon which are inscribed all generations of the world, their past and future deeds, rulers, and significant events, including the coming of Messiah ben Joseph and Messiah ben David, and the wars of Gog and Magog, illustrating divine omniscience and pre-determination.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XLVI: The place of the stars shown to R. Ishmael
structure_content.summary: Metatron shows R. Ishmael the stars standing on sparks of flames around the Merkaba, serving the world by providing light and singing hymns to the Creator. It is revealed that God will create these stars anew in the future age.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XLVII: Metatron shows R. Ishmael the spirits of the punished angels
structure_content.summary: Metatron displays the souls and spirits of ministering angels whose bodies were consumed by fire in the Nehar di-Nur for uttering the 'Song' at an improper time. Their spirits return to the Creator and stand behind the Shekina, indicating both pre-existence and bodily punishment for failing divine duty.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XLVIII (A): Metatron shows R. Ishmael the Right Hand of the Most High, now inactive behind Him, but in the future destined to work the deliverance of Israel
structure_content.summary: Metatron reveals God's Right Hand (MAQOM), currently inactive due to the destruction of the Holy Temple and Israel's sins. This Right Hand, which created 955 heavens and is beyond angelic comprehension, is destined to be activated in the future to work Israel's deliverance and establish God's Kingdom.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XLVIII (cont.) (B): The Divine Names that go forth from the Throne of Glory, crowned and escorted by numerous angelic hosts through the heavens and back again to the Throne—the angels sing the 'Holy' and the 'Blessed'
structure_content.summary: This section enumerates 70-72 Divine Names (including SS, SeDeQ, SaHPeL SUR, SBI, SaDdlQ, YeHOEL YaH, YOPHIEL, 'APHPHIEL, MaRGeZIEL, GIPpUYEL, Pa'aZIEL, 'A'aH, and Tetragrammaton permutations) that emanate from the Throne of Glory, crowned with fire and escorted by angelic hosts. These Names inspire the angelic Qedushsha chants.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XLVIII (cont.) (C): An Enoch-Metatron piece
structure_content.summary: Metatron, identified as Enoch, recounts God's transformation of him into a mighty, unique prince. He describes the removal of the Shekina due to the generation of the flood and his subsequent appointment over all heavenly treasuries and Halls of 'Araboth, where he wreathes crowns upon the Chayyoth, Ophannim, and Kerubim. He also teaches the prematurely dead and is called 'the LESSER YHWH'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter XLVIII (cont.) (D): The names of Metatron. The treasuries of Wisdom opened to Moses on mount Sinai. The angels protest against Metatron for revealing the secrets to Moses and are answered and rebuked by God. The chain of tradition and the power of the transmitted mysteries to heal diseases
structure_content.summary: Presents a list of Metatron's 70-72 names and details how Metatron facilitated the revelation of all treasuries of wisdom and Torah to Moses on Sinai. Angels protest this revelation to 'flesh and blood', but God rebukes them, affirming Metatron's unique role as His servant and the revealer of secrets, which possess the power to heal diseases.

key_concepts.definition: The central angelic figure, identified with Enoch son of Jared, who underwent a physical and spiritual transformation into a celestial prince. He is referred to as 'the Lesser YHWH', God's representative, Prince of the Presence, Knower of Secrets, and ruler over most angelic hierarchies. Metatron mediates divine will, reveals cosmic secrets, teaches departed souls, and acts as a scribe of divine decrees and human merits/iniquities. He is a living compendium of creation's cosmic letters.

The Divine Chariot, a complex celestial vehicle and seat of God's Glory, described with intricate components including wheels (Galgallim), living creatures (Chayyoth), Seraphim, Kerubim, and Ophannim. R. Ishmael undertakes a visionary ascent to behold its form and associated hierarchies.

The Divine Presence or Glory of God. Initially residing on Earth, it withdrew due to human idolatry. In the celestial realms, it rests upon the Chayyoth, radiates immense splendor, and is perceived as a protective, light-substance. The narrative emphasizes its removal from Earth and its presence within the Merkaba system.

Seven concentric heavenly palaces or chambers that R. Ishmael traverses during his ascent. These Halls contain various angelic hosts, the Merkaba, and ultimately the Throne of Glory. Their structure and inhabitants define a clear celestial hierarchy.

The angelic liturgical chant, 'Holy, Holy, Holy, is the Lord of Hosts; the whole earth is full of His glory!' (Isaiah 6:3). Its correct and timely utterance by angels is a meritorious act, rewarded with crowns, while incorrect performance leads to fiery punishment. It signifies divine sovereignty and maintains cosmic order.

Sacred appellations of God and Metatron (e.g., YAH 'EHYE 'ASHER 'EHYE, 'ESH 'OKELA, 'EL SHADDAI RABBA, 'OSE SHALOM, LESSER YHWH) that are explicitly associated with cosmic functions, maintaining balance of polar opposites, protection, healing, and acting as foundational creative forces. These names are often engraved on celestial objects like Metatron's crown or the Throne of Glory.

A river of burning fire issuing from beneath the Throne of Glory, derived from Daniel 7:10. It serves as a means of purification for angels (who bathe in it before performing Qedushsha) and as an instrument of punishment for the wicked and errant angels. It is depicted with vast measures and intense heat.

Four (or numerous) great princes identified as celestial court officers within the Great Beth Din in 'Araboth Raqia'. They assist God in daily judgment, exalting the humble and abasing the proud, and are involved in the execution of divine decrees.

A celestial ledger kept by the angel Radweriel, containing meticulously recorded deeds, thoughts, and destinies of all generations and individuals, both past and future. It serves as the foundational document for divine judgment.

A veil of Divine Majesty spread before the Holy One's Throne, upon which are engraven all generations of the world and their doings, past and future. It symbolizes divine omniscience and predestination, holding the hidden secrets of heaven and earth.

Mystical letters, revealed to Metatron and engraved upon his crown and the Throne of Glory, that constitute the fundamental building blocks and divine blueprints by which all elements of the created universe—heaven, earth, celestial bodies, and terrestrial features—were brought into existence.

practical_system.description: The book outlines a complex celestial system, primarily accessed through visionary ascent and mediated by Metatron. The operative mechanics are centered on gaining divine favor and understanding cosmic order by interacting with celestial hierarchies and divine names. While not a step-by-step grimoire, it implies that profound knowledge of divine structures, names, and angelic functions can grant spiritual power, protection, and insight into the universe's operation. The system suggests a strong emphasis on correct ritual performance and moral rectitude to align with divine will and navigate celestial realms.
tools: Knowledge of Divine Names: Extensive understanding of Metatron's names, names of the Holy One, and names governing elemental and cosmic forces (e.g., YAH 'EHYE 'ASHER 'EHYE, 'ESH 'OKELA, 'OSE SHALOM) for magical work, protection, and seeking divine favor.

Understanding of Angelic Hierarchy: Detailed knowledge of the ranks, functions, and epithets of various angelic classes (Seraphim, Chayyoth, Ophannim, Kerubim, Princes of Kingdoms, 'Irin, Qaddishin) to navigate celestial realms and correctly petition divine agents.

Cosmic Letters of Creation: The foundational letters engraved on Metatron's crown and the Throne of Glory, representing the blueprints of creation. Mastery of these letters is implied to grant insight into cosmic mechanics and potentially creative power.

Records and Books of Destiny: The 'Book of Records' (kept by Radweriel) and the 'Curtain of MAQOM' (engraven with all events) imply the use and study of similar textual records for understanding fate, human actions, and influencing outcomes.

Celestial Visions and Scrying: The visionary ascent and the showing of divine mysteries to R. Ishmael by Metatron suggest techniques for direct perception of celestial realities, potentially involving scrying or deep meditative states.
rituals: Visionary Ascent (Merkabah Mysticism): Direct experience through spiritual ascent, requiring intense prayer and possibly specific mental preparations, to behold the Divine Chariot and its surrounding angelic hosts, as performed by R. Ishmael.

Prayer and Supplication: Focused prayer directed towards the Holy One and Metatron, particularly upon entering celestial realms or seeking divine intervention and favor, as exemplified by R. Ishmael and the Patriarchs.

Utterance of Qedushsha (Holy Chant): The precise and timely chanting of the 'Holy' (Trisagion) by ministering angels is a meritorious act central to maintaining cosmic order. This implies that human practitioners might aim for similarly precise and reverent liturgical performance.

Purification Rites: The ritual bathing of angels in the Nehar di-Nur (Fiery River) before performing the Qedushsha suggests a requirement for extensive purification, likely through elemental or fiery means, for practitioners seeking to engage with celestial forces.

Engagement with Divine Names: The knowledge and utterance of various Divine Names (e.g., Metatron's 70/72 names, YHWH variations, creative names) for purposes of protection, cosmic balance, healing, and exerting influence over celestial and terrestrial destinies.

relevant_quotes.text: When I ascended on high to behold the vision of the Merkaba and had entered the six Halls, one within the other: as soon as I reached the door of the seventh Hall I stood still in prayer before the Holy One, blessed be He...
"My servants, my Seraphim, my Kerubim and rny 'Ophanniml Cover ye your eyes before Ishmael, my son, my friend, my beloved one and my glory, that he tremble not nor shudder!"
"Because I am Enoch, the son of Jared."
And He called me THE LESSER YHWH in the presence of all His heavenly household; as it is written (Ex. xxiii. 21): "For my name is in him."
"The judgement was set and the books were opened."

At the time that the Holy One, blessed be He, is sitting on the Throne of Judgement, then the angels of Mercy are standing on His right, the angels of Peace are standing on His left and the angels of Destruction are standing in front of Him.

Come, and I will show thee the Curtain of MAQOM (the Divine Majesty) which is spread before the Holy One, blessed be He, (and) whereon are graven all the generations of the world and all their doings, both what they have done and what they will do until the end of all generations.

critical_analysis.relevance: The 'Hebrew Book of Enoch' (3 Enoch or Sefer Hekhalot) is a pivotal text in Merkabah mysticism and foundational for understanding later Qabalistic developments. Its detailed cosmology, angelology, and unique portrayal of Metatron as the transfigured Enoch bridge early Enochic traditions with subsequent rabbinic and magical practices. The concept of Metatron as a supreme celestial being, God's vice-regent, and the ultimate source of revealed wisdom significantly influenced Hermetic Qabalah, grimoire traditions, and various forms of Jewish esotericism, particularly concerning angelic invocation and the understanding of divine names and cosmic governance. It outlines a highly structured celestial bureaucracy, where every action, from creation to judgment, is meticulously recorded and executed through divine agents.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This text is essential for scholars and practitioners of Jewish mysticism, Merkabah literature, Qabalah (especially Hermetic Qabalah), angelology, and Western Esotericism. It is particularly relevant for those interested in the historical development of occult cosmologies, angelic hierarchies, divine names, and the conceptual underpinnings of advanced angelic invocation or theurgic practices aiming for celestial ascent and divine knowledge.
